an4.158:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:

an4.158:1.3.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

an4.158:2.1.pli: “Yo hi koci, āvuso, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā cattāro dhamme attani samanupassati, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
an4.158:2.1.eng: “Reverends, any monk or nun who sees four things inside themselves should conclude:

an4.158:2.3.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’

an4.158:2.5.pli: Rāgavepullattaṃ, dosavepullattaṃ, mohavepullattaṃ, gambhīresu kho panassa ṭhānāṭhānesu paññācakkhu na kamati.
an4.158:2.5.eng: They have much greed, much hate, and much delusion; and their wisdom eye doesn’t go into the many deep matters.

an4.158:2.6.pli: Yo hi koci, āvuso, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā ime cattāro dhamme attani samanupassati, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
an4.158:2.6.eng: Any monk or nun who sees these four things inside themselves should conclude:

an4.158:2.8.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’

an4.158:3.1.pli: Yo hi koci, āvuso, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā cattāro dhamme attani samanupassati, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
an4.158:3.1.eng: Any monk or nun who sees four things inside themselves should conclude:

an4.158:3.3.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’

an4.158:3.5.pli: Rāgatanuttaṃ, dosatanuttaṃ, mohatanuttaṃ, gambhīresu kho panassa ṭhānāṭhānesu paññācakkhu kamati.
an4.158:3.5.eng: Their greed, hate, and delusion grow less; and their wisdom eye goes into the many deep matters.

an4.158:3.6.pli: Yo hi koci, āvuso, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā ime cattāro dhamme attani samanupassati, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
an4.158:3.6.eng: Any monk or nun who sees these four things inside themselves should conclude:

an4.158:3.8.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’”

an4.159:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an4.159:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an4.159:1.3.pli: Atha kho aññatarā bhikkhunī aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
an4.159:1.3.eng: And then a certain nun addressed a man,

an4.159:1.4.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yenayyo ānando tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena ayyassa ānandassa pāde sirasā vanda:
an4.159:1.4.eng: “Please, mister, go to Venerable Ānanda, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

an4.159:1.5.eng: ‘Sir, the nun named so-and-so is sick, suffering, and gravely ill.

an4.159:1.6.pli: Sā ayyassa ānandassa pāde sirasā vandatī’ti. Evañca vadehi:
an4.159:1.6.eng: She bows with her head to your feet.’ And then say:

an4.159:1.7.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, ayyo ānando yena bhikkhunupassayo yena sā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
an4.159:1.7.eng: ‘Sir, please go to the nuns’ quarters to visit that nun out of sympathy.’”

an4.159:1.8.pli: “Evaṃ, ayye”ti kho so puriso tassā bhikkhuniyā paṭissutvā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so puriso āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
an4.159:1.8.eng: “Yes, ma’am,” that man replied. He did as the nun asked.

an4.159:2.2.pli: Sā āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vandati, evañca vadeti:

an4.159:2.3.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, āyasmā ānando yena bhikkhunupassayo yena sā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.

an4.159:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena bhikkhunupassayo yena sā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami.
an4.159:3.1.eng: Then Ānanda robed up and went to the nuns’ quarters to visit that nun, taking his bowl and robe.

an4.159:3.2.pli: Addasā kho sā bhikkhunī āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
an4.159:3.2.eng: That nun saw Ānanda coming off in the distance.

an4.159:3.3.eng: She wrapped herself up from head to foot and laid down on her cot.

an4.159:3.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena sā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho āyasmā ānando taṃ bhikkhuniṃ etadavoca:
an4.159:3.4.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to her, and sat down on the seat spread out. Then Ānanda said to the nun:

an4.159:4.1.eng: “Sister, this body is produced by food. Relying on food,

an4.159:4.3.pli: Taṇhāsambhūto ayaṃ, bhagini, kāyo taṇhaṃ nissāya.
an4.159:4.3.eng: This body is produced by craving. Relying on craving,

an4.159:4.5.pli: Mānasambhūto ayaṃ, bhagini, kāyo mānaṃ nissāya.
an4.159:4.5.eng: This body is produced by conceit. Relying on conceit,

an4.159:4.7.eng: This body is produced by sex.

an4.159:4.8.eng: The Buddha spoke of breaking off everything to do with sex.

an4.159:5.1.eng: ‘This body is produced by food. Relying on food,

an4.159:5.2.pli: Āhāro pahātabbo’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ.
an4.159:5.2.eng: you should give up food.’ This is what I said,

an4.159:5.3.eng: but why did I say it?

an4.159:5.4.pli: Idha, bhagini, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso āhāraṃ āhāreti:
an4.159:5.4.eng: Take a mendicant who reflects rationally on the food that they eat:

an4.159:5.5.pli: ‘neva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya, yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā yāpanāya vihiṃsūparatiyā brahmacariyānuggahāya. Iti purāṇañca vedanaṃ paṭihaṅkhāmi, navañca vedanaṃ na uppādessāmi. Yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro cā’ti.
an4.159:5.5.eng: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will have the means to keep going, blamelessness, and a comfortable abiding.’

an4.159:5.6.pli: So aparena samayena āhāraṃ nissāya āhāraṃ pajahati.
an4.159:5.6.eng: After some time, relying on food, they give up food.

an4.159:5.7.pli: ‘Āhārasambhūto ayaṃ, bhagini, kāyo āhāraṃ nissāya āhāro pahātabbo’ti,

an4.159:5.8.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an4.159:5.8.eng: That’s why I said what I said.

an4.159:6.1.eng: ‘This body is produced by craving. Relying on craving,

an4.159:6.2.pli: Taṇhā pahātabbā’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ.
an4.159:6.2.eng: you should give up craving.’ This is what I said,

an4.159:6.3.eng: but why did I say it?

an4.159:6.4.eng: Take a mendicant who hears this:

an4.159:6.5.pli: ‘itthannāmo kira bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.
an4.159:6.5.eng: ‘They say that the mendicant named so-and-so has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an4.159:6.7.pli: ‘kudāssu nāma ahampi āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissāmī’ti.
an4.159:6.7.eng: ‘Oh, when will I too realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. …’

an4.159:6.8.pli: So aparena samayena taṇhaṃ nissāya taṇhaṃ pajahati.
an4.159:6.8.eng: After some time, relying on craving, they give up craving.

an4.159:6.9.pli: ‘Taṇhāsambhūto ayaṃ, bhagini, kāyo taṇhaṃ nissāya taṇhā pahātabbā’ti,

an4.159:6.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an4.159:6.10.eng: That’s why I said what I said.

an4.159:7.1.eng: ‘This body is produced by conceit. Relying on conceit,

an4.159:7.2.pli: Māno pahātabbo’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ.
an4.159:7.2.eng: you should give up conceit.’ This is what I said,

an4.159:7.3.eng: but why did I say it?

an4.159:7.4.eng: Take a mendicant who hears this:

an4.159:7.5.pli: ‘itthannāmo kira bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.
an4.159:7.5.eng: ‘They say that the mendicant named so-and-so has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an4.159:7.7.pli: ‘so hi nāma āyasmā āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati;
an4.159:7.7.eng: ‘Well, that venerable can realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. …

an4.159:7.9.pli: So aparena samayena mānaṃ nissāya mānaṃ pajahati.
an4.159:7.9.eng: After some time, relying on conceit, they give up conceit.

an4.159:7.10.pli: ‘Mānasambhūto ayaṃ, bhagini, kāyo, mānaṃ nissāya māno pahātabbo’ti,

an4.159:7.11.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an4.159:7.11.eng: That’s why I said what I said.

an4.159:8.2.eng: The Buddha spoke of breaking off everything to do with sex.’”

an4.159:9.1.pli: Atha kho sā bhikkhunī mañcakā vuṭṭhahitvā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā āyasmato ānandassa pādesu sirasā nipatitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
an4.159:9.1.eng: Then that nun rose from her cot, placed her robe over one shoulder, bowed with her head at Ānanda’s feet, and said,

an4.159:9.2.pli: “accayo maṃ, bhante, accagamā, yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yāhaṃ evamakāsiṃ.
an4.159:9.2.eng: “I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to act in that way.

an4.159:9.3.pli: Tassā me, bhante, ayyo ānando accayaṃ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu, āyatiṃ saṃvarāyā”ti.
an4.159:9.3.eng: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I can restrain myself in future.”

an4.159:9.4.pli: “Taggha taṃ, bhagini, accayo accagamā, yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yā tvaṃ evamakāsi.
an4.159:9.4.eng: “Indeed, sister, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to act in that way.

an4.159:9.5.pli: Yato ca kho tvaṃ, bhagini, accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikarosi, taṃ te mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma.
an4.159:9.5.eng: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.

an4.159:9.6.pli: Vuddhi hesā, bhagini, ariyassa vinaye yo accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikaroti āyatiṃ saṃvaraṃ āpajjatī”ti.
an4.159:9.6.eng: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”

an4.16:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of subtlety.

an4.16:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpasokhummena samannāgato hoti paramena;
an4.16:1.3.eng: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of form.

an4.16:1.4.pli: tena ca rūpasokhummena aññaṃ rūpasokhummaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na samanupassati;
an4.16:1.4.eng: They don’t see any other subtlety of form that’s better or finer than that,

an4.16:1.5.pli: tena ca rūpasokhummena aññaṃ rūpasokhummaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na pattheti.
an4.16:1.5.eng: nor do they aim for it.

an4.16:1.6.eng: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of feeling.

an4.16:1.7.pli: tena ca vedanāsokhummena aññaṃ vedanāsokhummaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na samanupassati;
an4.16:1.7.eng: They don’t see any other subtlety of feeling that’s better or finer than that,

an4.16:1.8.pli: tena ca vedanāsokhummena aññaṃ vedanāsokhummaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na pattheti.
an4.16:1.8.eng: nor do they aim for it.

an4.16:1.9.eng: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of perception.

an4.16:1.10.pli: tena ca saññāsokhummena aññaṃ saññāsokhummaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na samanupassati;
an4.16:1.10.eng: They don’t see any other subtlety of perception that’s better or finer than that,

an4.16:1.11.pli: tena ca saññāsokhummena aññaṃ saññāsokhummaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na pattheti.
an4.16:1.11.eng: nor do they aim for it.

an4.16:1.12.eng: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of choices.

an4.16:1.13.pli: tena ca saṅkhārasokhummena aññaṃ saṅkhārasokhummaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na samanupassati;
an4.16:1.13.eng: They don’t see any other subtlety of choices that’s better or finer than that,

an4.16:1.14.pli: tena ca saṅkhārasokhummena aññaṃ saṅkhārasokhummaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na pattheti.
an4.16:1.14.eng: nor do they aim for it.

an4.16:1.15.eng: These are the four kinds of subtlety.

an4.16:3.2.eng: peaceful, in love with the state of peace.

an4.16:3.4.eng: having vanquished Māra with his legions.”

an4.160:0.3.eng: The Training of a Holy One

an4.160:1.1.pli: “Sugato vā, bhikkhave, loke tiṭṭhamāno sugatavinayo vā tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an4.160:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a Holy One or a Holy One’s training remain in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

an4.160:2.1.eng: And who is a Holy One?

an4.160:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā.
an4.160:2.2.eng: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.

an4.160:3.1.eng: And what is the training of a Holy One?

an4.160:3.2.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
an4.160:3.2.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an4.160:3.3.eng: This is the training of a Holy One.

an4.160:3.4.pli: Evaṃ sugato vā, bhikkhave, loke tiṭṭhamāno sugatavinayo vā tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānanti.
an4.160:3.4.eng: This is how a Holy One or a Holy One’s training remain in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

an4.160:4.1.pli: Cattārome, bhikkhave, dhammā saddhammassa sammosāya antaradhānāya saṃvattanti.
an4.160:4.1.eng: These four things lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.

an4.160:4.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhū duggahitaṃ suttantaṃ pariyāpuṇanti dunnikkhittehi padabyañjanehi.
an4.160:4.3.eng: Firstly, the mendicants memorize discourses that they learned incorrectly, with misplaced words and phrases.

an4.160:4.4.pli: Dunnikkhittassa, bhikkhave, padabyañjanassa atthopi dunnayo hoti.
an4.160:4.4.eng: When the words and phrases are misplaced, the meaning is misinterpreted.

an4.160:4.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo dhammo saddhammassa sammosāya antaradhānāya saṃvattati.
an4.160:4.5.eng: This is the first thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.

an4.160:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū dubbacā honti dovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgatā akkhamā appadakkhiṇaggāhino anusāsaniṃ.
an4.160:5.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants are hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.

an4.160:5.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo dhammo saddhammassa sammosāya antaradhānāya saṃvattati.
an4.160:5.2.eng: This is the second thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.

an4.160:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ye te bhikkhū bahussutā āgatāgamā dhammadharā vinayadharā mātikādharā, te na sakkaccaṃ suttantaṃ paraṃ vācenti.
an4.160:6.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants who are very learned—inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—don’t carefully make others recite the discourses.

an4.160:6.2.pli: Tesaṃ accayena chinnamūlako suttanto hoti appaṭisaraṇo.
an4.160:6.2.eng: When they pass away, the discourses are cut off at the root, with no-one to preserve them.

an4.160:6.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo dhammo saddhammassa sammosāya antaradhānāya saṃvattati.
an4.160:6.3.eng: This is the third thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.

an4.160:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, therā bhikkhū bāhulikā honti sāthalikā, okkamane pubbaṅgamā, paviveke nikkhittadhurā, na vīriyaṃ ārabhanti appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an4.160:7.1.eng: Furthermore, the senior mendicants are indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, not rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an4.160:7.2.eng: Those who come after them follow their example.

an4.160:7.3.pli: Sāpi hoti bāhulikā sāthalikā, okkamane pubbaṅgamā, paviveke nikkhittadhurā, na vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an4.160:7.3.eng: They too become indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, not rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an4.160:7.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho dhammo saddhammassa sammosāya antaradhānāya saṃvattati.
an4.160:7.4.eng: This is the fourth thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.

an4.160:7.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro dhammā saddhammassa sammosāya antaradhānāya saṃvattantīti.
an4.160:7.5.eng: These are four things that lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.

an4.160:8.1.pli: Cattārome, bhikkhave, dhammā saddhammassa ṭhitiyā asammosāya anantaradhānāya saṃvattanti.
an4.160:8.1.eng: These four things lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.

an4.160:8.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhū suggahitaṃ suttantaṃ pariyāpuṇanti sunikkhittehi padabyañjanehi.
an4.160:8.3.eng: Firstly, the mendicants memorize discourses that have been learned correctly, with well placed words and phrases.

an4.160:8.4.pli: Sunikkhittassa, bhikkhave, padabyañjanassa atthopi sunayo hoti.
an4.160:8.4.eng: When the words and phrases are well placed, the meaning is interpreted correctly.

an4.160:8.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo dhammo saddhammassa ṭhitiyā asammosāya anantaradhānāya saṃvattati.
an4.160:8.5.eng: This is the first thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.

an4.160:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū suvacā honti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgatā khamā padakkhiṇaggāhino anusāsaniṃ.
an4.160:9.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants are easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.

an4.160:9.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo dhammo saddhammassa ṭhitiyā asammosāya anantaradhānāya saṃvattati.
an4.160:9.2.eng: This is the second thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.

an4.160:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ye te bhikkhū bahussutā āgatāgamā dhammadharā vinayadharā mātikādharā, te sakkaccaṃ suttantaṃ paraṃ vācenti.
an4.160:10.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants who are very learned—inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—carefully make others recite the discourses.

an4.160:10.2.pli: Tesaṃ accayena nacchinnamūlako suttanto hoti sappaṭisaraṇo.
an4.160:10.2.eng: When they pass away, the discourses aren’t cut off at the root, and they have someone to preserve them.

an4.160:10.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo dhammo saddhammassa ṭhitiyā asammosāya anantaradhānāya saṃvattati.
an4.160:10.3.eng: This is the third thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.

an4.160:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, therā bhikkhū na bāhulikā honti na sāthalikā, okkamane nikkhittadhurā, paviveke pubbaṅgamā, vīriyaṃ ārabhanti appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an4.160:11.1.eng: Furthermore, the senior mendicants are not indulgent or slack, nor are they backsliders; instead, they take the lead in seclusion, rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an4.160:11.2.eng: Those who come after them follow their example.

an4.160:11.3.pli: Sāpi hoti na bāhulikā na sāthalikā, okkamane nikkhittadhurā, paviveke pubbaṅgamā, vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an4.160:11.3.eng: They too aren’t indulgent or slack …

an4.160:11.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho dhammo saddhammassa ṭhitiyā asammosāya anantaradhānāya saṃvattati.
an4.160:11.4.eng: This is the fourth thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.

an4.160:11.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro dhammā saddhammassa ṭhitiyā asammosāya anantaradhānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
an4.160:11.5.eng: These are four things that lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.”

an4.161:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four ways of practice.

an4.161:1.5.eng: pleasant practice with slow insight, and

an4.161:1.7.eng: These are the four ways of practice.”

an4.162:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four ways of practice.

an4.162:1.5.eng: pleasant practice with slow insight, and

an4.162:2.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā?
an4.162:2.1.eng: And what’s the painful practice with slow insight?

an4.162:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyāpi tibbarāgajātiko hoti, abhikkhaṇaṃ rāgajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an4.162:2.2.eng: It’s when someone is ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They often feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring.

an4.162:2.3.pli: Pakatiyāpi tibbadosajātiko hoti, abhikkhaṇaṃ dosajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

an4.162:2.4.pli: Pakatiyāpi tibbamohajātiko hoti, abhikkhaṇaṃ mohajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

an4.162:2.5.eng: These five faculties manifest in them weakly:

an4.162:2.6.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.162:2.7.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ muduttā dandhaṃ ānantariyaṃ pāpuṇāti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.162:2.7.eng: Because of this, they only slowly attain the conditions for ending the defilements in the present life.

an4.162:2.8.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā.
an4.162:2.8.eng: This is called the painful practice with slow insight.

an4.162:3.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā?
an4.162:3.1.eng: And what’s the painful practice with swift insight?

an4.162:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyāpi tibbarāgajātiko hoti, abhikkhaṇaṃ rāgajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an4.162:3.2.eng: It’s when someone is ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They often feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring.

an4.162:3.3.pli: Pakatiyāpi tibbadosajātiko hoti, abhikkhaṇaṃ dosajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

an4.162:3.4.pli: Pakatiyāpi tibbamohajātiko hoti, abhikkhaṇaṃ mohajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

an4.162:3.5.eng: And these five faculties manifest in them strongly:

an4.162:3.6.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.162:3.7.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ adhimattattā khippaṃ ānantariyaṃ pāpuṇāti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.162:3.7.eng: Because of this, they swiftly attain the conditions for ending the defilements in the present life.

an4.162:3.8.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā.
an4.162:3.8.eng: This is called the painful practice with swift insight.

an4.162:4.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sukhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā?
an4.162:4.1.eng: And what’s pleasant practice with slow insight?

an4.162:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyāpi na tibbarāgajātiko hoti, nābhikkhaṇaṃ rāgajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an4.162:4.2.eng: It’s when someone is not ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They rarely feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring.

an4.162:4.3.pli: Pakatiyāpi na tibbadosajātiko hoti, nābhikkhaṇaṃ dosajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

an4.162:4.4.pli: Pakatiyāpi na tibbamohajātiko hoti, nābhikkhaṇaṃ mohajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

an4.162:4.5.eng: These five faculties manifest in them weakly:

an4.162:4.6.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.162:4.7.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ muduttā dandhaṃ ānantariyaṃ pāpuṇāti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.162:4.7.eng: Because of this, they only slowly attain the conditions for ending the defilements in the present life.

an4.162:4.8.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sukhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā.
an4.162:4.8.eng: This is called the pleasant practice with slow insight.

an4.162:5.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sukhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā?
an4.162:5.1.eng: And what’s the pleasant practice with swift insight?

an4.162:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyāpi na tibbarāgajātiko hoti, nābhikkhaṇaṃ rāgajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an4.162:5.2.eng: It’s when someone is not ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They rarely feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring.

an4.162:5.3.pli: Pakatiyāpi na tibbadosajātiko hoti, nābhikkhaṇaṃ dosajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

an4.162:5.4.pli: Pakatiyāpi na tibbamohajātiko hoti, nābhikkhaṇaṃ mohajaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

an4.162:5.5.eng: These five faculties manifest in them strongly:

an4.162:5.6.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.162:5.7.pli: So imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ adhimattattā khippaṃ ānantariyaṃ pāpuṇāti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.162:5.7.eng: Because of this, they swiftly attain the conditions for ending the defilements in the present life.

an4.162:5.8.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sukhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā.
an4.162:5.8.eng: This is called the pleasant practice with swift insight.

an4.162:5.9.eng: These are the four ways of practice.”
